newsitem.title: USA: Will it play in Peoria?.
newsitem.headline: Will it play in Peoria?.

text.p: Attacking some fellow politicians who disapprove of the new television ratings system, Congressman Billy Tauzin (R-La.) said Friday that lawmakers should reserve their opinions and let Americans judge the system.
To that end, Tauzin, who heads the House Subcommittee on Telecommunications, Trade and Consumer Protection, said he would hold a town meeting on the matter in Peoria, Ill.

"We're going to see how it plays in Peoria," Tauzin said, referring to the Midwestern U.S. city that became famous as a cross section of American demographics and a centre for testing new products and ideas.

Tauzin, whose views on limiting the role of government, caused him leave the Democratic Party three years ago, made his remarks before a group of entertainment industry representatives and journalists.
Under pressure from lawmakers who threatened to impose their own ratings, the television industry earlier this year began a voluntary ratings system.
Since the ratings began appearing on the air, the system has been criticised as confusing for parents and rife with inconsistencies.
